content: PoS has an interesting feature in terms of hard-forking - supporting both (or more) forks is economically rational for a staker unless the value of the other fork is lower than the node support costs (usually minimal, especially if client software supports both hard-forks). author: jgm
content:
Signatures in Ethereum 2 are a signature over `(data root,domain)`, where `domain` is a composite that includes the fork version.  So if the chain is ticking along at fork version `0` and a hard fork occurs to move to fork version `1`, an attestation for one fork will have a signature that will no longer verify for the other.

(Note that there are a few wrinkles here, but this should cover the particular question of "can I attest on both chains safely?")
